passages.text: Latin America | Diario
Diario | Latin America
Brazil, Hapvida, Itaúsa, Latam Energy, Rede D'Or

Brazil | Presidential Polls, rates, and markets. Lula's approval dropped in August, reversing gains from his trade dispute with Trump, while Tarcisio now leads him in a key poll for the first time. Despite Brazil's resilience to Trump's tariffs, Lula's declining popularity amid strong economic performance signals fatigue and disconnection with his base. A center- right shift in the electorate (given the rise of the evangelical church and PT fatigue in Northeast) suggests a setup for a reformist candidate in 2026, especially with Bolsonaro likely out. Markets could rally early if Tarcisio gains traction, given his expected market- friendly agenda as seen as Governor of Sao Paulo, in our view. Companies such as Assai, Bradesco, Magazine Luiza, Lojas Quero- Quero, Renner, the car rental companies, payments and infrastructure concessions are amongst the most sensitive players to the rates cycle. Our top picks in Brazil include Nubank, Banco do Brasil, Itausa, RD Health in LargeCaps and Alpargatas, Assai, C&A, GPS, SmartFit, Vivara in SMIDs.

Itaúsa (Buy) | Fireside Chat Key Takeaways. We provide our key takeaways from our fireside chat with Itaúsa CEO Alfredo Setubal and CFO Priscila Grecco. We believe Itaúsa will continue delivering superior NAV growth and a premium dividend yield with a disciplined investment track record and a solid balance sheet that provides a strong firepower and capital allocation flexibility over macro cycles. Record NAV discount unjustified, PT R\\(13.2 (R\)12.6) to reflect higher NAV est. (+5%), Reiterate Buy.

Hapvida (Hold) | Fireside Chat Invite. We are hosting a virtual group meeting with Hapvida's IR Director Guilherme Nahuz on Wednesday, September 10, 2025 at 10am ET | 11am BRT | 3pm BST. Hapvida is the main health insurer in Brazil. It operates through a verticalized model, owning hospitals and clinics to serve its clients more efficiently. The company serves more than 8.5 million clients, almost 20% of the total health insurance users. Register here

Rede D'Or (Buy) | Fireside Chat Invite. We are hosting a virtual group meeting with Rede D'Or's CFO Otávio Lazcano on Thursday, September 11, 2025 at 10am ET | 11am BRT | 3pm BST. Rede D'Or is the biggest healthcare group in Brazil. It operates 76 hospitals and oncology and diagnostic clinics. In 2023, it expanded to health insurance by acquiring SulAmerica, one of the main health insurers in the country. Register here

Latam Energy | Jefferies Virtual LatAm Energy Conference. We are pleased to invite you to attend Jefferies' 2nd Virtual Latin American Energy Conference, taking place virtually on 23/24/25 September 2025. The summit will bring together institutional investors and a selection of 18 public and private companies from across the Latin American energy sector, with the addition of Central Puerto as new event participant. The format will consist of 1x1's and small group meetings (no presentations). Register Here

We provide our key takeaways from our fireside chat with Itaúsa CEO Alfredo Setubal and CFO Priscila Grecco. We believe Itaúsa will continue delivering superior NAV growth and a premium dividend yield with a disciplined investment track record and a solid balance sheet that provides a strong firepower and capital allocation flexibility over macro cycles. Record NAV discount unjustified, PT R\$13.2 (R \(12.6) to reflect higher NAV est. (+5\%), Reiterate Buy.

Capital Structure & Liquidity. Itaúsa has pivoted from aggressive investment to a defensive posture, prioritizing balance sheet strength and long- term resilience. This reflects prudent risk management amid Brazil's volatile macroeconomic landscape and global uncertainties. The company's deleveraging strategy has significantly reduced net debt, with long- duration debentures extending debt maturities beyond 2030. This positions Itaúsa to weather political cycles and interest rate fluctuations without liquidity constraints.

Investment Pause. Itaúsa halted new investments due to Brazil's fiscal and political uncertainties, high interest rates, and global instability. The last major investment was in CCR (now Motiva) in 2022. Since then, the company has adopted a cautious stance due to Brazil's fiscal and political uncertainties and global instability. Itaúsa invested cR\$11bn between 2017 and 2022, funded through debentures and proceeds from XP disposal.

Debt Reduction. Itaúsa has been primarily focused on debt reduction and refinancing, with net debt currently below R\$1bn, or less than \(1\%\) of NAV. New debentures have been issued at favorable rates (CDI \(+0.6\%\) , down from \(+1.37\%\) ) with no major amortization until 2030. Itaúsa has focused on deleveraging since 2023, refinancing debt with longer maturities and lower spreads as with the recent 10- year debenture.

Banking disruption to stay. Itaú continues to outperform with robust ROE and tech leadership. The bank's cloud migration and digital banking initiatives enhance competitiveness against fintech disruptors. Retail efficiency remains a challenge though, with a focus on AI and digital transformation. Itaú is migrating to cloud infrastructure (targeting \(100\%\) by 2027) and expanding its tech workforce to \(\sim 17,000\) . The bank's excess capital generation supports Itaúsa's dividend stability and optionality for future cash distributions. Itaú continues outperforming the sector with a stable ROE of \(23 - 24\%\) despite competitive pressures.

Selective Investment Approach. Itaú remains the core holding, representing \(90\%\) of NAV. Other key platforms include Motiva (mobility), Copa Energia (energy), and sanitation. Potential new investments likely to remain on existing portfolio companies rather than new verticals. Investments in companies such as Motiva, Copa and the sanitation sector are viewed as scalable platforms with consolidation potential. Despite its \(25\%\) share of Brazil's GDP, Itaúsa remains cautious on agro due to commodity price volatility.

Asset under restructuring. Alpargatas recovering post- pandemic following operational missteps, with new management improving logistics and simplifying product and channel strategy. Dexco has been challenged by the interest rates cycle affecting real estate demand, exploring asset sales to reduce debt. Motiva is refocusing on road concessions following the planned airports exit.

NAV Discount Unjustified. Current discount to NAV at \(25\%\) to \(28\%\) is unjustified, in our view, especially given the current yield (c \(10\%\) ). Extra dividends expected to remain on excess capital and limited lending growth at Itaú, a pass through to Itaúsa shareholders. Fiscal reform is expected to eliminate R\$600m/ year in tax inefficiencies by 2027, potentially increasing distributable cash. Preference remains on debt reduction unless buybacks become significantly more advantageous primarily driven by rates cycle.
Source:Jefferies,Company data

We are hosting a virtual group meeting with Havpida's IR Director Guilherme Nahuz on Wednesday, September 10, 2025 at 10am ET | 11am BRT | 3pm BST. Havpida is the main health insurer in Brazil. It operates through a verticalized model, owning hospitals and clinics to serve its clients more efficiently. The company serves more than 8.5 million clients, almost \(20\%\) of the total health insurance users. Register here

Havpida's background. The company dates back to 1978, but entered the health insurance market in 1993 and adopted a verticalized model in 2004. Since its IPO in 2018, it has expanded aggressively through acquisitions and become Brazil's largest healthcare operator merging with Notre Dame Intermédica. Today, it servers over 8.5 million beneficiaries and has a \(20\%\) share.

The vertical model. The company adopted its innovative verticalized model in 2004, integrating hospitals, clinics, and labs under one roof. This structure enables superior cost control, operational efficiency, and service standardization - creating a competitive edge more difficult to replicate. Additionally, the vertical model allows Havpida to be the lowest- cost provider in the industry, which is especially valuable during economic downturns - when clients tend to trade down to more affordable plans. Although the model turns healthcare units into cost centers, instead of profit centers, Havpida still manages to deliver a \(20\% - 25\%\) normalized ROE.

Growth prospects. While the healthcare industry faces structural challenges - such as modest beneficiary growth, intense competition, and limited product differentiation - Havpida's scale, efficiency, and defensive positioning offer resilience. The company continues to deliver post- merger and seems confident about its growth prospects.

Capital constraints. Tax and capital structure complexities remain, but Havpida is actively working to unlock significant value from a BRL\\$40bn in goodwill and optimize its corporate setup. Potential changes in capital requirements and/or faster goodwill incorporation could further enhance its equity value.
The invitee. Guilherme Nahuz has 20 years of corporate experience, having coordinated the IR departments of Wilson Sons and SuAmerica. He holds an MBA and an MSc in Finance from Boston
College, and a BSc from University of Massachusetts Lowell. He has been Hapvida's IR Director for over 6 years.

We are hosting a virtual group meeting with Rede D'Or's CFO Otávio Lazcano on Thursday, September 11, 2025 at 10am ET | 11am BRT | 3pm BST. Rede D'Or is the biggest healthcare group in Brazil. It operates 76 hospitals and oncology and diagnostic clinics. In 2023, it expanded to health insurance by acquiring SulAmerica, one of the main health insurers in the country. Register here

Rede D'Or São Luiz has a long- standing presence in Brazil's healthcare sector. Founded by Dr. Jorge Moll and beginning in 1977 as a diagnostic clinic in Rio de Janeiro, the company transitioned into hospital operations in 1998 and expanded rapidly through acquisitions and new developments. Today, it stands as Brazil's largest independent private hospital network, operating 75 hospitals and 61 oncology clinics, with over 106,000 accredited doctors across 14 metropolitan regions.

Rede D'Or evolved into an integrated and irreplaceable healthcare company. Today, it also encompasses insurance, oncology, diagnostics, and research. The scale has enabled it to achieve operational efficiencies and to attract top- tier medical professionals, which in turn reinforces its brand reputation among patients and makes it an essential partner for healthcare payers.

Its expansion strategy has been a blend of acquisitions and disciplined organic growth. M&As, with strong post- acquisition performance, offer as high returns on invested capital as greenfield projects. Following its IPO and excluding SulAmerica insurance revenues, the company doubled revenues since 2020 (5- year CAGR of c.16%) driven by the addition of 5,392 beds, 70% of 2020's base.

Growth ahead. Rede D'Or would add 1,660 beds, or 16% of current base, by returning its utilization rates to historical levels. No further relevant investments are attached to the maturation of these beds. In addition, Rede D'Or has a pipeline of 3,203 additional beds planned through 2028, representing 25% growth over its current capacity - mostly brownfields, which historically yield a 40% ROIC.

Strategic moves. The acquisition of SulAmerica has proven to be correct. Initially unexpected and feared by the market, it enhances Rede D'Or's organic growth capabilities. Moreover, having returned to profitability after COVID turmoil and claims ratio adjustments, it is now positioned to grow. Besides that, the joint venture with Bradesco Saúde turns the second- biggest healthcare insurer player into an ally and its beneficiary base would considerably help Rede D'Or to operationalize existing and to- be- added beds.

Upside potential. For hospital segment, upside could come from new project announcements, faster- than- expected bed utilization, and sustained ticket growth. For SulAmerica, stronger beneficiary growth and stable claims ratios would reinforce its value in a low- differentiation market.

The invitee. Otávio Lazcano has over 30 years of corporate experience. He served as Treasurer at Aracruz Celulose (currently Suzano), as CFO at CSN, executive officer at Prumo Logística, and partner and investment manager at BTG Pactual. He holds an MBA from Fundação Dom Cabral, and a BSc in Economics from Faculdades Cândido Mendes. Otávio Lazcano has been in Rede D'Or since 2015.

Brazil | Presidential Polls, rates, and marketsRecent presidential polls. Brazilian President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva's disapproval rate reached an all- time high in April, according to Reuters, but had since been recovering with lower food inflation and Trump's pressure. However, according to a survey conducted by AtlasIntel for Bloomberg News published yesterday, his popularity ebbed in August, suggesting the momentum he gained from a trade fight with Donald Trump may have been short- lived. Lula's approval fell to \(48\%\) down 2pp from July, according to LatAm Pulse, while disapproval rose 1pp to \(51\%\) . The poll also gave Tarcisio \(48.4\%\) and Lula \(46.6\%\) , a technical tie, but the first time Tarcisio leads it, and no other candidate tested comes close to challenging Lula.

Lula's disapproval in a supposedly favorable scenario. Fears of Trump's pressure as a tailwind for Lula had previously led to higher yields and volatility in particular for domestic plays such as banks and consumer. Brazil held up better than initially feared after Trump's \(50\%\) "political" tariff as direct exports exposure is relatively limited across public equities with a couple of exceptions. Lula's weaker support in an economy that has beaten estimates for four years in a row suggests some signs of fatigue and some disconnection with its electoral base. The key question is whether he can still press the (nuclear) fiscal spending button in an attempt to regain popular support ahead of elections. All eyes are on the US \(30bn\) Bolsa Familia handouts program.

Center- right electorate shift to create an unprecedented scenario? A recent study by Mar Asset, as reported by Brazil Journal, suggests Brazil electorate has shifted toward the center- right over the past decade, creating a different setup for the 2026 election even with Jair Bolsonaro likely out of the race. Hence, there is scope for a reformist, center- right candidate could win and govern with an aligned Congress- an unprecedented outcome that could unlock long- term economic growth and structural reforms. In addition to the right- leaning congress, Lula's path to reelection is narrower than in 2022, constrained by the rising influence of the evangelical church, and the limited room for expansion of the PT strongholds like the Northeast. This alignment between executive and legislative branches could be a powerful catalyst for Brazilian assets.

Market (out)performance in center- right win? We expect the MT performance of Brazilian equities to be influenced mostly by the outcome of Oct- 26 general elections. We believe a big rally in equities/rates could come early if the market anticipates Tarcisio as a potential winner who aims for a policy regime change. Tarcisio's political agenda would be expected by the market to be market- friendly and not shy on the much- needed fiscal front, with elevated Congressional support overall. Local institutional investors have experienced equity outflows for the last 3 years given the rates cycle as the money sits comfortably in fixed income waiting for a sign of a change in the rates cycle, which appears to be largely driven by political change, being it a fiscal strategy or a government change.

Our picks. Brazil real rates are down by almost 200bps from the late February high \((10.5\%)\) , but volatile and largely driven by sentiment over political change in the next year election. The market rally remains supported by interest driven domestic stocks including C&A \((+119\%\) YTD in BRL) and Assai \((+89\%)\) . Domestic companies and SMIDs in particular are more sensitive to the rates cycle. Our Brazil top picks include Nubank, Banco do Brasil, RD Health, Itausa, Alpargatas, Assai, C&A, SmartFit and Vivara. Companies such as Assai, Bradesco, Magazine Luiza, Lojas Quero- Quero, Renner, the car rental companies, payments and infrastructure concessions are amongst the most sensitive players to the rates cycle.

Disclosures.action or call 212.284.2300.

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period. NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies' methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment

themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a 15% stop loss, and the remainder will have a 20% stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
